# Description
[output](https://training.bksec.vn/apiv2/files/local/bq5QlwvHjm14MEAB2xuVE?iat=1770523800&sig=NBNhqCHW92sGYkynkrlVHQgr_dyV6TexQc1hXLUuUbI)
## My solution
The $gcd(e1,e2)=5$ so we can run an algorithm similar to `gcd()` to find $c \equiv m^5  \quad mod(n)$ ($m$ here is the flag). Note that the flag has 52 bytes,
so $m^5$ is around 2080 bits long, slightly bigger than $n$, 2047 bits. Bruteforce finding $k$ until $k*N+c$ is a perfect power.
```
def cal_gcd(e1,e2,c1,c2,n):
    if(e1==0):
        return e2,c2
    if(e2==0):
        return e1,c1
    if(e1<e2):
        c1,c2=c2,c1
        e1,e2=e2,e1
    q=e1//e2
    new_e=e1 - q*e2
    new_c=c1*inverse(pow(c2,q,n),n)%n
    return cal_gcd(new_e,e2,new_c,c2,n)
        
n = 
e1 = 23526945546700
e2 = 46104058382895
c1 = 
c2 = 
e,c=cal_gcd(e1,e2,c1,c2,n)
for i in range(2**33):
    goal=i*n + c
    root,exact=iroot(goal,5)
    if exact:
        print(long_to_bytes(root))
        break
```
